member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.BuildDetail.StatusChanging
member.summary: Raised when any change in the build details is discovered on the server. Note: to receive these events you must call the Connect method, which causes the server to be polled on a regular basis until the build is finished. This event is fired just before the build details are updated in this object.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.BuildDetail.StatusChanged
member.summary: Raised when any change in the build details is discovered on the server. Note: to receive these events you must call the Connect method, which causes the server to be polled on a regular basis until the build is finished. This event is fired just after the build details are updated in this object.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.BuildDetail.PollingCompleted
member.summary: Raised when polling completes. Note: to receive this event you must call the Connect method. This event is fired when polling completes, either because the build finished or because an unrecoverable error was encountered (e.g. the build was deleted).

member.name: T:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.InformationNodeConverters
member.summary: The InformationNodeConverters class can be used to add IBuildInformationNodes of various types to an IBuildDetail, or get IBuildInformationNodes of various types from an IBuildDetail. In both cases, return values of the various static methods will typically be helper interface types, such as IBuildStep or IConfigurationSummary. These types serve to simplify access to the underlying IBuildInformationNode objects.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.InformationNodeConverters.AddBuildStep(Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDetail,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a top-level build step to a build with a start time of DateTime.Now. Saves to the server. Note that build steps are no longer used after TFS 2008 and have been replaced with various new information node types, including IBuildMessage, IBuildError, IBuildWarning, and IActivityTracking. As such, when adding information nodes to builds which will primarily be viewed from 2010 clients (and later), these new types are preferable to IBuildSteps.
member.param: The build.
The name of the build step to be added.
The message of the build step to be added.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.InformationNodeConverters.GetBuildSteps(Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDetail)
member.summary: Gets a sorted list of all the build steps from a build. Note that build steps are no longer used after TFS 2008 and have been replaced with various new information node types, including IBuildMessage, IBuildError, IBuildWarning, and IActivityTracking. As a result, this method will typically return an empty list when talking to a 2010 server or later (the server version can be determined from the IBuildServer.BuildServerVersion property).
member.param: The build.
member.returns: The sorted list of build steps. Sorting is done first by hierarchy, then by start time, and finally by ID.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.InformationNodeConverters.GetBuildSteps(Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildInformation)
member.summary: Gets a sorted list of all the build steps from a build. Note that build steps are no longer used after TFS 2008 and have been replaced with various new information node types, including IBuildMessage, IBuildError, IBuildWarning, and IActivityTracking. As a result, this method will typically return an empty list when talking to a 2010 server or later (the server version can be determined from the IBuildServer.BuildServerVersion property).

member.name: P:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDefinition.ContinuousIntegrationQuietPeriod
member.summary: The quiet period associated with a 'Batch' continuous integration type. New builds will not be queued for changesets which are encountered during the quiet period. Instead a single build will be queued for all changesets which occurred during the quiet period once it has lapsed. This value is used as an offset (in minutes) from the starting time of the last queued build for Continuous Integration.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDetail.Connect(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.ComponentModel.ISynchronizeInvoke)
member.summary: Starts polling, using the specified interval, timeout and ISynchronizeInvoke object. When the StatusChanging, StatusChanged, or PollingCompleted events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.
member.param: The polling interval, in milliseconds.
The timeout, in milliseconds.
The object used to synchronize polling events. If null, events will be fired on a thread pool thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDetail.Connect(System.Int32,System.ComponentModel.ISynchronizeInvoke)
member.summary: Starts polling, using the specified interval and ISynchronizeInvoke object. When the StatusChanging, StatusChanged, or PollingCompleted events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.
member.param: The polling interval, in milliseconds.
The object used to synchronize polling events. If null, events will be fired on a thread pool thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDetail.Connect
member.summary: Starts polling, using the default interval of five seconds and no synchronization object. Events will be fired on a thread pool thread. When events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, the other overload should be used for this method and that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDetail.StatusChanging
member.summary: Raised when any change in the build is discovered on the server. Note: to receive these events you must call the Connect method, which causes the server to be polled on a regular basis until the build is finished. This event is fired just before the build is updated.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDetail.StatusChanged
member.summary: Raised when any change in the build is discovered on the server. Note: to receive these events you must call the Connect method, which causes the server to be polled on a regular basis until the build is finished. This event is fired just after the build is updated.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildDetail.PollingCompleted
member.summary: Raised when polling completes. Note: to receive this event you must call the Connect method. This event is fired when polling completes, either because the build finished or because an unrecoverable error was encountered (e.g. the build was deleted).

member.name: P:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IBuildRequest.GatedCheckInTicket
member.summary: Optional ticket issued by the server for gated check-in submissions. When a check-in is rejected due to Gated Check-in a GatedCheckinException is thrown. The gated check-in ticket is available on the exception and should be used when submitting the build request to the build system. Setting this property from the exception allows a rejected check-in to be queued by a user who does not have the appropriate permissions to perform the action under normal circumstances.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuild.Connect(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.ComponentModel.ISynchronizeInvoke)
member.summary: Starts polling, using the specified interval and ISynchronizeInvoke object. When the StatusChanged, or PollingCompleted events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.
member.param: The polling interval, in milliseconds.
The timeout, in milliseconds.
The object used to synchronize polling events. If null, events will be fired on a thread pool thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuild.Connect
member.summary: Starts polling, using the default interval of five seconds and no synchronization object. Events will be fired on a thread pool thread. When events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, the other overload should be used for this method and that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuild.Copy(Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuild,Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.QueryOptions)
member.summary: Copies the data from the queued build into the current instance. The return value indicates whether or not anything in the queued build was actually updated that would effect state.
member.param: The source of the copy operation
The options used to query the copy source
member.returns: True if the build state changed, false otherwise

The overall timeout of the blocking call

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuild.StatusChanged
member.summary: Raised when any change in the queued build is discovered on the server. Note: to receive these events you must call the Connect method, which causes the server to be polled on a regular basis until the queued build is complete. This event is fired just after the queued build is updated.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuild.PollingCompleted
member.summary: Raised when polling completes. Note: to receive this event you must call the Connect method. This event is fired when polling completes, either because the queued build finished or because an unrecoverable error was encountered (e.g. the queued build was deleted).

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuildsView.Connect(System.Int32,System.ComponentModel.ISynchronizeInvoke)
member.summary: Starts polling, using the specified interval and ISynchronizeInvoke object. When the StatusChanging or StatusChanged events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.
member.param: The polling interval, in milliseconds.
The object used to synchronize polling events. If null, events will be fired on a thread pool thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuildsView.Connect
member.summary: Starts polling, using the default interval of thirty seconds and no synchronization object. Events will be fired on a thread pool thread. When events are handled by a visual Windows Forms component, the other overload should be used for this method and that component should be passed in as the synchronizingObject so that the event handlers are called on the same thread on which the component was created.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuildsView.Disconnect
member.summary: Stops polling.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuildsView.Refresh(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Manually refreshes the view, and optionally removes completed builds from the view.
member.param: If false, all completed builds are removed from the view immediately. If true, only those completed builds outside of the completed window are removed from the view.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuildsView.StatusChanging
member.summary: Raised once for each polling interval. Note: to receive these events you must call the Connect method, which causes the server to be polled on a regular basis until the Disconnect method is called. This event is fired just before the contents of the view (and the queued builds themselves) are updated.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.IQueuedBuildsView.StatusChanged
member.summary: Raised once for each polling interval. Note: to receive these events you must call the Connect method, which causes the server to be polled on a regular basis until the Disconnect method is called. This event is fired just after the contents of the view (and the queued builds themselves) are updated.

member.name: T:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.DefinitionQueueStatus
member.summary: Specifies the status of a definition queue.

member.name: F:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.DefinitionQueueStatus.Disabled
member.summary: When disabled the definition queue will not allow builds to be queued by users and the system will not queue scheduled, gated or continuous integration builds. Builds already in the queue will not be started by the system.

member.name: F:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.DefinitionQueueStatus.Enabled
member.summary: When enabled the definition queue allows builds to be queued by users, the system will queue scheduled, gated and continuous integration builds, and the queued builds will be started by the system.

member.name: F:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.DefinitionQueueStatus.Paused
member.summary: When paused the definition queue allows builds to be queued by users and the system will queue scheduled, gated and continuous integration builds. Builds in the queue will not be started by the system.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.QueuedBuild.StatusChanged
member.summary: Raised when any change in the build details is discovered on the server. Note: to receive these events you must call the Connect method, which causes the server to be polled on a regular basis until the build is finished. This event is fired just after the build details are updated in this object.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.QueuedBuild.PollingCompleted
member.summary: Raised when polling completes. Note: to receive this event you must call the Connect method. This event is fired when polling completes, either because the build finished or because an unrecoverable error was encountered (e.g. the build was deleted).

member.summary: Starts polling, using the default interval of thirty seconds and no synchronization object. Events will be fired on a thread pool thread.

member.summary: Starts polling, using the specified interval and ISynchronizeInvoke object.
member.param: The polling interval, in milliseconds.
The object used to synchronize polling events. If null, events will be fired on a thread pool thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.QueuedBuildsView.Disconnect
member.summary: Stops polling on the build queue.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.QueuedBuildsView.Refresh(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Manually refreshes the build queue. This will remove any Completed builds from the queue.

member.name: M:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.QueuedBuildsView.RefreshInternal(Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.PollingAlgorithm)
member.summary: Refreshes the build queue during polling. Completed builds will stay in the queue for the completed window. This method is executed on a background thread. The polling class is passed into this method because our reference can get set to null on another thread.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.QueuedBuildsView.StatusChanging
member.summary: Raised when any change in the contents of the build queue is discovered on the server. Note: to receive these events you must call the Connect method, which causes the server to be polled on a regular basis until the Disconnect method is called. This event is fired just before the contents of the queue (and the queued builds themselves) are updated.

member.name: E:Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Build.Client.QueuedBuildsView.StatusChanged
member.summary: Raised when any change in the contents of the build queue is discovered on the server. Note: to receive these events you must call the Connect method, which causes the server to be polled on a regular basis until the Disconnect method is called. This event is fired just after the contents of the queue (and the queued builds themselves) are updated.

member.summary: Update the queue contents with the latest query results.
member.param: The latest query results.
member.returns: True if the queue list has changed sinced last refresh, false otherwise

members.member: Returns a localized string given a resource string name.
Returns a localized integer given a resource string name.
Returns a localized string given a resource string name.

A little helper function to alleviate some typing associated with loading resources and formatting the strings. In DEBUG builds, it also asserts that the number of format arguments and the length of args match.
